intro: Heuchera elegans var. hirsuta, commonly known as the hairy coral bells, is a herbaceous perennial native to the eastern United States. It features dense, upright clusters of showy, bell-shaped flowers in shades of pink, red, and white, which bloom from late spring to early summer. The plant has hairy, serrated leaves that are typically bronze, red, or purple, providing ornamental value even when not in bloom. It thrives in partial to full shade and moist, well-drained soil, making it a popular choice for woodland gardens. Its foliage and flowers attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies, contributing to ecological diversity in the garden.
